clinical_study.brief_title: Randomized Study Comparing Two Established Gastrointestinal Suture Techniques - One-layer-continuous Versus Double-layer-continuous Suture
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Trial to Compare Two Gastrointestinal Anastomosis Techniques - Single Layer Continuous Versus Double Layer Continuous

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine the frequency of postoperative complications depending on the number of suture layers in colo-colonic and ileo-colonic anastomoses Hypothesis: double-layer suture has less anastomotic leakages compared to single-layer suture.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Feasibility reasons; recruitment was too slow.

secondary_outcome.measure: death of any cause within 3 months post-operatively
secondary_outcome.description: all causes of death will be recorded independently of a possible causal relationship with the operation

arm_group.description: Hand-sutured end-to-end or end-to-side anastomosis performed by double-layer continuous technique (monofil thread)
Hand-sutured end-to-end or end-to-side anastomosis performed by single-layer continuous technique (monofil thread).

intervention.description: Hand-sutured end-to-end or end-to-side anastomosis performed by double-layer continuous technique (monofil thread)
Hand-sutured end-to-end or end-to-side anastomosis performed by single-layer continuous technique (monofil thread)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- at least 18 years old,
- planned for elective surgery
- at least one hand-sutured ileo-colonic or colo-colonic anastomosis
Exclusion Criteria:
- ASA-Score > 3,
- missing written consent of the informed patient
- no existing choice between suture-techniques according to the surgeon
- patient not able to cooperate/non-compliance
- rectal anastomoses
